reasoning:
The critique targets the essay’s key probabilistic framing: likelihood of mostly-great futures conditional on “no serious, coordinated efforts to promote overall best outcomes de dicto.” That framing matters because the essay uses it to support the claim that mostly-great futures are a narrow target ‘by default’; if the conditioning is illegitimate or question-begging, a significant part of the argumentative force is undermined (moderately high centrality). However, much of the essay’s case for “no easy eutopia” is not purely empirical/probabilistic but also normative/structural (fragility, multiplicative-factor model, fussiness of many plausible moral theories). Even if the ‘default distribution’ is too pessimistic, the essay could still maintain that value is fragile and that without strong steering, large value losses are plausible—so the critique doesn’t fully collapse the position (centrality < 1).

On strength: the critique plausibly presses that the ‘default’ reference class may be defined in a way that excludes dynamics that could arise without “serious coordinated efforts” (institutional learning, competition, AI-mediated deliberation). That would weaken the inference from “fussy moral views” to “unlikely to hit mostly-great absent explicit de dicto optimization,” because the excluded dynamics might still steer toward high value. But the critique overreaches in implying the essay “packs all goodness into serious coordinated effort”: the essay explicitly separates (1) target size from (2) navigation/aiming and (3) many attempts, and says it focuses on (1). Also, the conditioning clause is not obviously vacuous: the essay is trying to isolate the ‘big target’ hypothesis from deliberate optimization, and it can coherently count some governance/learning dynamics as present while excluding explicit de dicto optimization. Because the critique doesn’t demonstrate that the essay must exclude those dynamics, it only partially refutes the attacked component.

Correctness is fairly high: it’s true that the conditioning can, if interpreted strongly, bias the probability estimate downward and risk triviality (“define default to exclude improvement forces”). But some specific claims (“quietly removes precisely the mechanisms most likely…”) are interpretive and not clearly established from the text alone, lowering correctness somewhat.

Clarity is high: it states a single, identifiable objection (possible definitional/selection bias in the conditioning/reference class) and explains the alleged triviality.

Dead weight is low: nearly all sentences support the one objection.

Single-issue is maximal: it focuses on one core point.

Overall: the critique is a decent, focused challenge to one important step (the ‘by default’ likelihood framing), but it does not strongly undermine the broader multi-pronged argument for eutopian fragility and moral fussiness, and it relies on a disputable reading of what the conditioning clause excludes.
title: Defining "default" to exclude improvement mechanisms makes the thesis trivially true
